Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as d193e0082c3fc7d4f4c34dd5fa86e95c036c938d

Could we just do this?

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/74028

but we are assuming that only password and totp are valid prompts. In general multifactor auth can have more than that. So I don't see any harm being a bit futuristic here. This will support for all possible prompts required by any pam modules other than google authenticator. Are you worried about the performance ? Even if you prefer hardcoding password and totp, I would prefer delegating the parsing logic to  PamData or PasswordData.

> but we are assuming that only password and totp are valid prompts.

Not really.  the token key is set to nullopt, so if we ever got it on the password prompt (which seems unlikely) we'd stil return the same error.

> In general multifactor auth can have more than that. So I don't see any harm being a bit futuristic here.

I do.  Lets make things complicated when we need things to be complicated.  I really suspect there's less than 10 prompts we could potentially answer assuming we imlemented the whole world of PAM.  That's not enough to justify trying to create a bunch of dynamic structures.

> This will support for all possible prompts required by any pam modules other than google authenticator.

How do you know this?  Have you tried all possible prompts?  Is there a reason the prior if/else if tree couldn't handle all possible prompts?

> Are you worried about the performance ? Even if you prefer hardcoding password and totp, I would prefer delegating the parsing logic to  PamData or PasswordData.

No, I'm worried about complexity, and strings being built at runtime (which is harder to audit).  Lets write simple code until we prove that we need something.
If we wanted to replace the unordered_map with a std::array<std::pair<key, value>> I'd be more ok with that, because the size would be fixed and able to be easily audited.

How do you know this? Have you tried all possible prompts? Is there a reason the prior if/else if tree couldn't handle all possible prompts?

yes, before deciding on google authenticator we explore other options for which the prompts were different. 

Even in this case, just to verify TOTP we don't need password, which is required in  secret key generation flow. 

I can change the container to std::array with length of 2. It is not a problem for me.
Acknowledged
We only have 2 fixed sets of keys, the second of which the key is shared.  Why do we need to convert the underlying data structure to this?  It seems like overkill.

We only have 2 fixed sets of keys.

This assumption is what I was trying to avoid.If you wanted to hardcode it only for two keys, then I  don't have anything else to say.

In general 
1) I will never go for the previous solution of miss using reinterpret_cast that wrongly cast a const char* to PasswordData. 
2) Keeping the prompt parsing code inside pamFunctionConversation does not seems to be good design practice. IMO it should go inside PasswordData.
3) Personally I don't see any overkill in replacing hard coded if else chain with find_if algorithm. 
4) if we use find_if and key_value pair ,it give extra benefit of supporting MFA with different keys with negligible performance cost.  

Anyway it is maintainers choice to take it or not. We can agree to disagree on the overkill statement above.

One functional requirement of this patch is the addition of Totp::verify function. Which is a must for google authentication createSecretKey flow. We just need to verify the totp, without password. One extra argument is the new pam module name that does just the totp verification part.

> We only have 2 fixed sets of keys.
> 
> This assumption is what I was trying to avoid.If you wanted to hardcode it only for two keys, then I  don't have anything else to say.

Today we only have 2 sets of keys.  If we get significantly more, we can certainly talk about changing this data structure, but to my understanding, I see google OTP being added, and that's it, right?

FWIW, this struct ended up a lot more complex.

> 
> In general 
> 1) I will never go for the previous solution of miss using reinterpret_cast that wrongly cast a const char* to PasswordData. 

Yes, obviously.  I have opened https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/74028 to fix that.

> 2) Keeping the prompt parsing code inside pamFunctionConversation does not seems to be good design practice. IMO it should go inside PasswordData.


Could you do this refactor in a different patchset?  I agree with it, so it might make this simpler to review.

> 3) Personally I don't see any overkill in replacing hard coded if else chain with find_if algorithm. 

It's +35 lines of code.  Considering there's 2 conditions, that seems like a lot to me.  If there were 10 conditions, I'm sure my feelings would be different.

> 4) if we use find_if and key_value pair ,it give extra benefit of supporting MFA with different keys with negligible performance cost.  

Lets revisit that once we have more keys that we're adding.  FWIW, when we did this same analysis for doing Redfish -> Dbus conversions, the if/else ladder beat everything, including std::arrays.

> 
> Anyway it is maintainers choice to take it or not. We can agree to disagree on the overkill statement above.
> 
> One functional requirement of this patch is the addition of Totp::verify function. Which is a must for google authentication createSecretKey flow. We just need to verify the totp, without password. One extra argument is the new pam module name that does just the totp verification part.


I don't quite understand this part.  Is it possible to extract that portion into its own patch?
Done

I'm struggling a little bit to see why we would want this kind of thing at this time (given we only support 2 prompts).

I could certainly see if we start supporting 10+ prompts how this could be better, but as-is, it's more code, and has problems in it.  I personally find the old code easier to read, but some struct like this isn't much worse.

Because it's looking like this patch isn't going to merge quickly, can we get https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/74028 reviewed and tested so that we've unbroken master (and I don't have to revert the previous TOTP patch), and we can revisit this once that's done.

I have mentioned the reason for this patch above. What I am missing in this patch is the proper explanations in the commit. Otherwise I don't have much to change. If you wanted to reject this patch please go ahead, I can stop working on it. All I want is new Top Verification method with a given pam module name , user name and  a totp. If you can add that feature it is great.

Ok, so in the hopes of having a better discussion, I've separated out the code move, from the new function added, from the generic data structure.  I think each probably need reviewed in isolation to have a fruitful review.
agreed. Let me test it with our MFA implementation. Will create separate patch for Totp Verify.
Done
Why is the token optional in PasswordData? Same reason here.
Because tokens can be optionally provided.  I guess that makes sense.
Done
Any reason we're checking this?
this is already there in previous patch as well. look at line 52 of removed code
Done
These strings previously had spaces after them.
Does it matter ? are we not just checking if it starts with "Password"? Is it mandatory to check for space?
Why did this patch remove them is the question I'm asking.
I can put it back. I did not remove it deliberately.
Done
Why do we declare a struct with a single static member?  Just make a method.
That is matter of preference. I thought Totp::varify() looks better than varifyTotp(). Finally it is maintainers call. I am ok with anything.

> That is matter of preference. I thought Totp::varify() looks better than varifyTotp(). Finally it is maintainers call. I am ok with anything.

Lets do the later.  That's in line with what we do other places.
Done
Documented Common error.
Done

now that all keys are optional in this struct, should we just omit the ones that aren't provided, rather than track a std::optional here?


std::pair<std::string_view, std::string_view>;

Where if a token is provided, you get

"Password: ", "<user password>",
"Verification code: ", "<token>"

or if a token isn't provided, we just have 

"Password: ", "<user password>",


That seems a lot simpler of a struct?
I was thinking about the same. But that makes another if check while creating the PasswordData. For eg: in pamAuthenticateUser function. The current implementation will take care of both case.
I still think it's an improvement regardless of having to add that check during creation.
Done
why value_or here?  We checked this has a value on the line 2 lines up.
can't call data() on a string view without size().  The string isn't necessarily null terminated.

you mean value_or("").data() is error? or strdup(promptDataIter->second.data()); is error? 
a quick check on std::string_view("").length() gave me zero.
This code is need to silent the clang-tidy
with out this cland-tidy was throwing error. It was a strange error. The has_value check is already there , but clang-tidy still complains.
Use operator<bool> instead of has_value().

std::string_view::data() is not null terminated.  You've passed it into an API that expects null terminated.

Not sure about the tidy error, but lets get this written in a simple way, and we can figure out the tidy issue.
changed the optional to actual value. Now only prompts with value will be present in the PasswordData. Checks has to be done at caller side
Done
Done
Why was this broken out?  It's essentially one branch that we've just duplicated
just to improve the readability. will make it inline if you want.
keep it inline please.  breaking out one branch doesn't improve readability IMO
Done
Why do we need PasswordData::KVPair on one constructor and not the other?

std::string(password) would have done the trick. I will change it back. 
Compiler just need a hint to deduce the type of pair.
changed the implementation to use addPrompt API
Done
Done
Should we just use std::vector here?  The additional malloc doesn't concern me, and it would make the push code simpler.
Done
Should we return an error here?
Done

nit, for consistency use size().

This is doing a different check than we were before.  This is checking the message we got is below a size, we need to check the response is below a size.

In addition, now that we have addPrompt, we should enforce the length check there, as we can return an error faster that way.
Acknowledged

I like this API better.

Can we:

1. make addPrompt take 2 args, so we're not having to construct the pair at the call site.
2. Make the constructor take no args so we're consistently calling addPrompt for each prompt we want to handle?
Done
Pretty minor updates to this, then this patch should be good to go.
I don't think this is true anymore.
Done
Remove the using declaration here.  Responses isn't used anywhere else, and std::vector<Response> isn't that much longer of a declaration than Response
Done
Should be != PAM_SUCCESS
Done
We should return whatever error code was given here.
Done
Same here.
Done

can't we just do

std::string(value) here?
That makes it same old issue , string_view need not end with '\0'. What we need to is substring represented by string_view. So is the need of size()

That's fine this is a string.  string is directly constructable from string view without needing the pointer/length constructor.

constructor #16 here:
https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/string/basic_string/basic_string
Fixed it for you.
This looks like it was added?  Why?  Should we do that in its own commit?
This is required ,These prompts are from password change . I believe your older commit faced with regression due to same reason when you tried to reuse same pam conv function.

> This is required 
>,These prompts are from password change . I believe your older commit faced with regression due to same reason when you tried to reuse same pam conv function.

That's fine, please still put it in its own commit, and mark that it's a fix of a regression and the hash where the regression happened.  I'm a little confused because I don't recall there ever being a reply for "Retype new password", but we'll cross that bridge once we know what's going on.

To be clear, you're testing on a bmc, and not on your dev desktop, right?

I am it testing on Romulus emulator.

 I don't recall there ever being a reply for "Retype new password"
 
 This was not needed before because before we were having single data (password) and for any prompt request pam_conv function returns the single data. After we introduced multiple data (like totp token) we started checking for the prompt string to figure out the proper data to be returned.
you can see the same prompt appearing in bmc ,if you trying to changes password using ssh
I was talking about this regression fix https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/74028/9 . Which is not needed if we do this change
ack
